result.markdown:
--- title: Sternoclavicular Joint (SCJ) --- The sternoclavicular joint is a synovial saddle joint # Muscles # Connective tissue # Joint Structure Since the SCJ is a saddle joint, both the distal and proximal joint surfaces have concave and convex facets. - Frontal plane: - Convex clavicle on Concave sternum - Superior roll and inferior slide - Transverse plane: - Concave clavicle on convex sternum - Anterior roll and slide - 6° upward slope - Posterior to the frontal plane 20 deg # Kinematics The sternoclavicular joint has 3 degrees of freedom: 1. **Frontal plane**: [Elevation](#elevation) & [Depression](#depression) 1. **Transverse plane**: [Protraction](#protraction) & [Retraction](#retraction) 1. **Sagittal plane**: [Anterior rotation](#anterior-rotation) and [Posterior rotation](#posterior-rotation) These movements combine to place the scapula in a position to optimally accept the head of the humerus @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. As a result, all of the functional movements at the [glenohumeral joint]({{< var ref-glenohumeral-joint.path >}}) involve SCJ movement. ## Elevation {#elevation} - The SCJ has 35-45° of elevation @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - Endrange elevation is limited by the [costoclavicular ligament]({{< var ref-costoclavicular-ligament.path >}}). In open kinetic chain, elevation involves the movement of the convex clavicle on the concave sternum. As a result, the convex clavicle rolls *superiorly* and slides inferiorly @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. In closed chain, the concave sternum rolls superiorly and slides superiorly on the convex clavicle. ## Depression {#depression} - The SCJ has ~10° of depression from neutral @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - Endrange depression stretches the i[nterclavicular ligament]({{< var ref-interclavicular-ligament.path >}}) and the superior portion of the capsular ligaments @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - In Open kinetic chain, the convex clavicle rolls *inferiorly* and slides *superiorly* on the concave sternum @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - In closed chain, the concave sternum rolls and slides *inferiorly* on the convex clavicle. ## Protraction {#protraction} - Protraction and retraction both have ~15-30° from neutral @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - This movement occurs in the transverse or horizontal plane around the vertical axis of rotation @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - During open kinetic chain protraction, the concave clavicle rolls and slides anteriorly on the convex sternum @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - Closed chain protraction involves the convex sternum rolling anteriorly and sliding posteriorly. This movement is limited by: - [Posterior bundle of the costoclavicular ligament]({{< var ref-costoclavicular-ligament.path >}}) - Posterior capsular ligament of the SC joint @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - Scapular retractor muscles @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - [Rhomboid major]({{< var ref-rhomboid-major.path >}}) - [Rhomboid minor]({{< var ref-rhomboid-minor.path >}}) - [Middle trapezius]({{< var ref-middle-trapezius.path >}}) ## Retraction {#retraction} - This movement occurs in the transverse or horizontal plane around the vertical axis of rotation @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - Protraction and retraction both have ~15-30° from neutral @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - Endrange retraction stretches the [*anterior bundles* of the costoclavicular ligament]({{< var ref-costoclavicular-ligament.path >}}) and the anterior capsular ligaments @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - During open kinetic chain retraction, the concave clavicle rolls and slides *posteriorly* on the convex sternum @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - Closed chain retraction involves the convex sternum *posteriorly* rolling and *anteriorly* sliding on the concave clavicle. ## Anterior rotation {#anterior-rotation} - Refers to rotation around the longitudinal axis @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - Rotation (post) 40-50° ## Posterior rotation {#posterior-rotation} - Refers to rotation around the longitudinal axis @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - The SCJ can perform ~20-35° of posterior rotation @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - This motion involves arthrokinematic spin and does not follow the convex-concave rule @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. - Posterior rotation is important in [posterior tilt of the scapulothoraic joint]({{< var ref-scapulothoracic-joint.posterior-tilt >}}). This motion is important during full flexion and abduction of the shoulder @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. # Functional movements The clavicle and therefore the SCJ requires rotation in all 3 degrees of freedom when raising the arm overhead @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. # Palpation {#palpation} To palpate the sternoclavicular joint: - Locate the *suprasternal notch*, which can be found on the superior aspect of the manubrium @finandoTriggerPointTherapy2005. - Move laterally from the *suprasternal notch* to the sternoclavicular joint @finandoTriggerPointTherapy2005. - Alternating elevation and depression of the shoulder while palpating the joint will help you to clearly distinguish between the [manubrium]({{< var ref-sternum-bone.manubrium >}}) and the [clavicle]({{< var ref-clavicle-bone.path >}}) @finandoTriggerPointTherapy2005. ::: {.callout-note} At the sternoclavicular joint, the [clavicle]({{< var ref-clavicle-bone.path >}}) is raised slightly above the manubrium at the articulation @finandoTriggerPointTherapy2005. ::: # Stabilization Tissues that stabilize the SCJ: ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ### Passive Stabilizers - Anterior sternoclavicular joint ligament @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - Posterior sternoclavicular joint ligament @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - Interclavicular ligament @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - Costoclavicular ligament @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - Articular disc @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 ::: ::: {.column} ### Active Stabilizers - [Subclavius]({{< var ref-subclavius.path >}}) [@duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020; @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020; @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017] - [Sternocleidomastoid]({{< var ref-sternocleidomastoid.path >}}) @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - [Sternothyroid]({{< var ref-sternothyroid.path >}}) @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - [Sternohyoid]({{< var ref-sternohyoid.path >}}) @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 ::: ::: ::: {#tbl-sternoclavicular-joint-stabilizer-muscles-oian .cell message='false' tbl-cap='Sternoclavicular joint stabilizer muscles' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Warning: No 'path' link found for variable 'nan' in YAML data. Warning: No 'path' link found for variable 'nan' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'None' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'None' in YAML data. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Sternocleidomastoid Manubrium
Medial third of Clavicle		 Mastoid process
Superior nuchal line		 CN XI Accessory n.
Cervical plexus
C1 - C4		 Unilateral: I/L cervical sidebend, C/L cervical rotation
Bilateral: Head extension, Cervical Flexion, Assists in respiration, Prevents posterior translation during mastication
SCJ stabilization
Sternohyoid SCJ: Stabilization
Sternothyroid SCJ: Stabilization
Subclavius 1st rib Clavicle (inferior surface) N. to subclavius
C5 - C6		 SCJ: Clavicular stabilization
``` ::: ::: # Clinical Significance Biomechanical studies have shown a variation of 15-31 degrees in the SC joint through the rotation of the clavicle during the movements of the arm in the frontal plane (abduction) and less in the sagittal plane (flexion) @ludewigThreedimensionalClavicularMotion2004 (Ludewig et al. 2004) # Clinical Presentation AROM limitations - ABD is most limited when missing a clavicle # Joint Mobilization ## Anterior mobilization {#anterior-mobilization} An anterior mobilization of the SCJ is indicated for patients who have both passive and active protraction ROM limitations due to structural impairments @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. ### Technique - Patient position: supine - Face the patient - Hook the pads of fingers 2-5 on the posterosuperior aspect of the clavicle - Place both thumbs on the posteroinferior aspect of the clavicle Apply an *anterior* mobilization by pulling the clavicle anteriorly @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. ## Posterior Glide {#posterior-mobilization} A posterior mobilization is indicated to improve retraction range of motion @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. A posterior mobilization of the SCJ is indicated for patients who have both passive and active retraction ROM limitations due to structural impediments @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. ### Technique - Face the patient - Place the inside thumb on the anterior and proximal aspect of the clavicle @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. - Place the dorsal surface of the middle phalanx of the index finger just inferior to your thumb to add support @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. Apply a posterior mobilization by pushing your thumb finger in a *posterior* direction @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. ## Superior mobilization {#superior-mobilization} A Superior glide is indicated for patients with limited passive *and* active ROM deficits for SCJ depression @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. ### Technique - Face the patient - Place the inside thumb on the anterior and proximal aspect of the clavicle @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. - Place the dorsal surface of the middle phalanx of the index finger on the inferior surface of the clavicle @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. Apply a superior mobilizing Force by pushing your index finger in a superior direction @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. ## Inferior mobilization {#inferior-mobilization} An inferior mobilization of the SCJ is indicated for patients who have both passive and active *elevation* ROM limitations due to structural impairments @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018. ### Supine technique - Patient position: supine - Face the patient - Hook the pads of fingers 2-5 of both hands on the superior aspect of the clavicle - Place both thumbs on the inferior aspect of the clavicle Apply an *inferior* mobilization by pulling the clavicle inferiorly @kisnerTherapeuticExerciseFoundations2018.
